properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 38 are expected tonight. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm (highest amounts over extreme southern areas). Time span: overnight tonight into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain will change to rain tonight and taper to showers Wednesday morning. Significant snowmelt and runoff are likely to occur. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T10:59:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T19:00:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3449078138.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula Southeast, Avalon Peninsula Southwest

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow will transition through a period of ice pellets this evening before changing through freezing rain to rain later tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 35 cm is expected. Locations: Corner Brook and Gros Morne. Time span: this evening into Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow and wind will combine to reduce visibility at times in blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. In the Corner Brook area, snow will likely mix with ice pellets overnight tonight and early Wednesday morning. Conditions will improve Wednesday afternoon as snow tapers off to flurries. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds will cause blowing snow tonight and Wednesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme cold wind chill values near minus 55 are expected return on Wednesday afternoon as winds increase. As the winds pick up tomorrow, it is likely that blowing snow will occasionally reduce visibility to less than 400 m. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for tonight and Wednesday. Lake effect snow bands and heavy flurries will move into the region tonight and shift back and forth across the region through Wednesday morning giving variable amounts of snow. Local amounts of 5 to 10 centimetres of snow can be expected by Wednesday morning. The heavier bands of snow will likely move north of Sault Ste. Marie on Wednesday morning. Travel may become hazardous at times tonight and on Wednesday due to accumulating snow and slippery conditions. Visibility could locally be reduced at times in heavy flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls moving in off of Georgian Bay are expected to extend into the area this evening and overnight. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T14:42:56-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for early Wednesday morning. Travel conditions will once again become hazardous early Wednesday morning due to accumulating snow and local blowing snow and will continue into the afternoon. An additional 5 cm of snow will be possible. Motorists are advised to take care on the roads as the snow starts to accumulate once again. Slow down and maintain a safe following distance. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T15:15:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T23:16:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0191220692.2021
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Moreover, winds combined with the snow will cause blowing snow in exposed areas this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T12:37:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T20:38:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3152632157.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow, ice pellets, and an extended period of freezing rain are expected tonight. Total snowfall and ice pellet amounts: 15 to 20 cm. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine. Time Span: ending tonight. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets will change over to ice pellets then freezing rain early this evening and end later tonight. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T10:59:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T19:46:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4064914674.2021
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls continue to affect areas near Lake Huron this evening. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 15 cm is still possible. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T08:09:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T23:31:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0982441192.2021
Area: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls will move in off of Lake Huron this evening and will likely remain overnight. The snow squalls will be transient across the area. This snow is expected to be heavy at times and local accumulations of 10 to 20 cm is possible with highest accumulations likely near Lake Huron. Strong winds and gusts of up to 50 km/h are expected to produce local blowing snow which could reduce visibility significantly. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-17T15:26:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-16T23:28:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0281884476.2021

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Avalon, Burin, and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: tonight. Freezing rain amounts: 5 to 10 mm. Remarks: After a period of snow and ice pellets this evening, precipitation will transition through an extended period of freezing rain later tonight. Freezing rain will change to rain prior to morning on Wednesday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-17T10:59:07-00:00
